column2: AT&T; sues Cox Communications for patent infringement Aug 29 AT&T; is suing Cox Communications for infringing eight patents dealing with network quality after the regional cable provider ignored its complaints about the issue and made "billions" off of the technology

column3: China Unicom to build car charging outlets across China SHANGHAI U.S. electric carmaker Tesla Motors  said on Friday that it would partner with China's No.2 mobile carrier China Unicom  to build charging outlets across the country to push sales in the world's biggest auto market.

column2: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Aug 29 Aug 29 The following are the top stories in the Wall Street Journal. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
Johnson & Johnson to seek buyer for medical device maker unit -WSJ Aug 28 Johnson & Johnson plans to seek a buyer for its medical device maker business
column4: The Wall Street Journal reported citing people familiar with the matter.

column3: Lilly lose bid to overturn $9 bln award for hiding cancer risk Aug 28 Takeda Pharmaceuticals and Eli Lilly & Co lost a bid to overthrow a combined $9 billion punitive-damage award by a U.S. jury for hiding cancer risks associated with their Actos diabetes drug
Japan defence planners seek spending boost * Another destroyer wanted for North Korea defence   (Adds details

column2: McDonald's says 12 Russian branches temporarily closed MOSCOW
column3: Aug 29 McDonald's said on Friday that a total of 12 of its branches in Russia had been temporarily closed over the state food safety regulator's allegations of sanitary violations.

column2: U.S. judge lifts suspension on Microsoft overseas email seizure NEW YORK
column3: Aug 29 A judge on Friday lifted a suspension on her order directing Microsoft Corp to turn over a customer's emails stored overseas to U.S. prosecutors.

column2: Pratt suspended F-35 engine shipments in May over titaniumUPDATE 1-Pratt halted F-35 engine shipments in May over titanium Aug 29 United Technologies Corp's Pratt & Whitney unit briefly suspended delivery of the engine for the F-35 Joint Strike  Fighter jet in May because of questions about titanium provided to a parts supplier.
